comments.html: That exclamation mark is useful in one other subtle little way.  If you've typed out a really long command and just realized that you need to go enable something else first, you can CNTL-A and add in the exclamation mark.  Hit return and go do what's in need of doing.  Then you can up arrow back and do another CNTL-A to remove the exclamation.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:

Ahh, the lucky ones that use Linux as the default operating system :)

@Scott: That's simply brilliant. Thanks for sharing this tip.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
Is it only me not getting timestamps in front of user generated logs (7600/SRB2)?

%SYS-7-USERLOG: Message from 1(XXX): TEST
%SYS-2-USERLOG: Message from 1(XXX): TEST2

"service timestamps log" is configured and normal logs include the timestamp in front of them.
comments.name: Tassos

comments.html: @Tassos: Have you configured "service timestamps debug"? Sometimes Cisco IOS has a weird idea what "debugging" and "logging" is.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Yes, both log & debug are configured.
comments.name: Tassos

comments.html:
ok, 6500/SXH3a shows it fine (using a different message!), but it doesn't give you the option to define a custom severity level (having 2 as default!).

Nov 24 19:54:32: %SYS-2-LOGMSG: Message from 1(XXX): TEST

I guess Cisco is still experimenting with it.
comments.name: Tassos

comments.html: In which version of IOS that command has been implemented? Is there any way to log a message with a different facility as well?
comments.name: Anonymous
